title: God
comment: The Creator and Redeemer of the world, who reveals himself in Scripture and in Jesus Christ, and who is loved, worshipped and adored by believers. Scripture stresses the personal nature of God, and also his total reliability and trustworthiness. God is the Father of Jesus Christ and of all believers.

children.title: God, all-knowing
children.comment: The omniscience of God is that attribute by which he knows all things past, present and future. What is hidden from human sight is still known by God. Scripture stresses the wisdom of God in all his actions, and often grounds this in his all-embracing knowledge.

children.title: God's unique self-knowledge within the Trinity
God knows things that are hidden from human understanding
God's knowledge of people's hearts and minds

primaryrefs.comment: Scripture views the heart not primarily as the seat of emotion but more particularly as the seat of the will.

secondaryrefs.comment: God's knowledge of Abimelech's motives and behaviour towards Abraham's wife Sarah
the LORD to Samuel regarding David's anointing as king
God's knowledge of the deception of Ananias and Sapphira

children.title: God's foreknowledge of Jesus Christ's passion
God's foreknowledge of those who would become disciples
God's foreknowledge of people's free actions
God's knowledge ensures that all will be judged fairly
God's knowledge ensures that he knows those who are his
God, anger of
children.comment: The punitive and vindicatory reaction, legitimate and controlled, yet awesomely emphatic, of God the righteous judge to unrighteousness in his human creatures. Up to the present, the expression of God's anger and wrath has had the purpose of drawing sinners to repentance and conversion, but this will not be the case at the final judgment.

children.title: It is consistant with his righteous and merciful character

seealsos.comment: Josiah removes idolatrous shrines
the unbelief of rejecting the Son of God

children.title: Ungodly living
children.precomment: God's judgment against the ungodly is a sign of his anger against actions that contradict his righteous character and purposes:

children.title: Complaints against, and opposition to, God's purposes
On a future ``day of wrath'' which is anticipated
God allows those who reject righteousness to remain in their sin
Punishment will be experienced by rebellious people
God will be feared as his holiness and greatness are revealed
Ultimately God will purify and restore his people for service
God, compassion of
children.comment: An aspect of God's nature which is reflected in his sympathetic understanding of human weakness and his restoration of those in trouble.

children.title: God shows compassion as a parent
God shows compassion to those in deep trouble
The return from exile shows God's compassion to sinners
God's compassion is essential to believers' well-being
God's compassion is reflected in acts of human compassion
God, faithfulness of
children.comment: God's perfect loyalty and consistency in being true to his name, his character and his word.

children.title: God's faithfulness is an integral part of his nature

primaryrefs.comment: God's limitless power and steadfast love imply complete faithfulness which contrasts with human nature

children.title: God is faithful to his name and character
God's faithfulness is known through fulfilled promises
Examples of God's faithfulness in fulfilled promises

primaryrefs.comment: God's faithfulness will not always mean human prosperity.

children.title: God's faithfulness is revealed to the faithful

primaryrefs.comment: God's faithfulness is not negated by human unfaithfulness.

children.title: Jesus Christ is the ultimate evidence of God's faithfulness
God, fatherhood of
children.comment: Primarily signifying God's paternal relationship to Jesus Christ, the term also refers to God's fatherly relationship to his creation, especially to believers as the ``children of God''.

children.title: Aspects of the fatherhood of God
He is the Creator and provider
He exercises his providence and care
God as the Father of Jesus Christ
God is the father of Israel
He cares for his covenant people
He is the father of the kings of Israel

primaryrefs.comment: This description of God's fatherhood involves the maintenance of a special relationship between God and David's descendants, which ultimately includes Jesus Christ.

children.title: God is the father of Christian believers
He has an intimate relationship with believers
He adopts believers into his family
The fatherhood of God has implications for the church
Character: children are to reproduce the Father's likeness
Unity: one Father means one family
Status: believers are related to Jesus Christ
Inheritance: believers are heirs of the Father's kingdom
Submission: believers are to revere the Father
God, glory of
children.comment: The revelation of God's power and characteristics, sometimes accompanied by visible phenomena.

children.title: Glory as an attribute of God
God's glory in the tabernacle and the temple

primaryrefs.comment: The Jewish term for the outward sign of God's presence in the temple is ``Shekinah''.

children.title: God's glory cannot be fully seen

seealsos.comment: Moses
Isaiah
the shepherds

children.title: God's glory brings guilt and fear
God, goodness of
children.comment: All God's perfect qualities are made freely available to all for the benefit of the whole world.

children.title: God's goodness is to be experienced
God is good to those who trust him
God's people can rely on his goodness
God works positively for good in unfavourable circumstances
God's goodness is to be praised
God, grace and mercy of
children.comment: The qualities of God's character by which he shows himself compassionate, accepting, and generous to sinful human beings, shielding them from his wrath, forgiving them, and bestowing on them his righteousness so that they can live and grow in faith and obedience. Grace and mercy are particularly expressed through God's covenant with his chosen people and through Jesus Christ's atoning death on the cross.

children.title: God's grace and mercy are made known in Jesus Christ
The abundance of God's grace and mercy
God's grace and mercy are always unearned and unmerited
God's grace and mercy are a source of blessing
God's grace and mercy are expressed in the covenant relationship

primaryrefs.comment: Hebrew ``hesed'' (translated as ``love'', ``loving-kindness'', ``unfailing love'') expresses specifically the grace and mercy that underlie the covenant relationship.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's words to his disciples

children.title: This is ultimately shown in the cross of Jesus Christ
God's grace and mercy are offered to sinners
Examples of those who found favour with God
Examples of those who seek the favour of God
Promises relating to the favour of God

secondaryrefs.comment: It is given to the obedient (see Lev 26:3)
It is given to the righteous

children.title: The OT predicts a future age of God's favour
Implications for believers of the grace and mercy of God
God's grace and mercy are to influence the character and conduct of believers
Believers must humbly rely on God's grace and mercy
God's grace strengthens believers for service
Illustrations of God's grace and mercy
children.precomment: God shows grace to Noah, saving him from the flood and afterwards establishing a covenant with him:

secondaryrefs.comment: God shows mercy in saving first Jonah and then (following their repentance) the people of Nineveh
The forgiving love of the prodigal's father illustrates the divine mercy of God.

children.title: God, greatness of
children.comment: God's nature, deeds and attributes are incomparable, for which he deserves all praise.

primaryrefs.comment: God's powerful acts are often associated with the exodus.

seealsos.comment: His great power at work in the resurrection

children.title: God's power is known in the nations
God must be praised for his greatness
He is greater than other gods
God is greater than human power and pride
God, holiness of
children.comment: The moral excellence of God that unifies his attributes and is expressed through his actions, setting him apart from all others. Believers are called to be holy as God is holy.

primaryrefs.comment: David's palace was regarded as holy because of the presence of the ark

seealsos.comment: The Jews accused Paul of defiling the temple area by bringing in Gentiles
the church as the dwelling in which God lives by his Spirit

children.title: God's holiness is revealed in his righteous activity
Coming before a holy God requires preparation
Special requirements and tasks are given to worship leaders
God's holiness is to be seen in his people
God's people are to be holy because he is holy

seealsos.comment: the church is to be pure as the bride of Jesus Christ
a qualification for an elder

children.title: Becoming holy involves striving after God
The holiness of believers originates from God
God's holiness makes sin objectionable to him
God's holiness necessitates dependence upon him for forgiveness
God, joy of
children.comment: God rejoices in the well-being and faithfulness of his covenant people, and in the repentance and conversion of sinners. He brings joy to his people, who rejoice in his presence and faithfulness.

children.title: God is the source of joy
God rejoices in the restoration of his people

seealsos.comment: He rejoices as does a bridegroom
He rejoices as does a father

children.title: Joy can be found in the heavenly presence of God
God's face shining on his people

primaryrefs.comment: When God's face shines on his people his divine pleasure and joy is implied.

children.title: God, justice of
children.comment: The moral righteousness of God is revealed in his laws and expressed in his judicial acts.  God's commands and judgments meet perfect standards of justice, and his apportioning of punishments and rewards is also perfectly just.  God's justice is impartial.  Special praise is his for vindicating the penitent and the needy who have no human champions. Ultimately, all God's ways will be seen as just and equitable.

children.title: It conforms to his moral law
It is seen in his perfect will
God's justice is exercised fairly and equitably
He judges people according to their deeds
He upholds the cause of the oppressed
He vindicates those who have been wronged
God's justice is not always immediately apparent
God gives opportunity for people to change their ways
God's justice is satisfied by the work of Jesus Christ
God's justice will be established in the reign of Jesus Christ
Heaven and earth will rejoice when God's justice is established
God requires people to reflect his justice
God, living and self-sustaining
children.comment: God is alive and active. In contrast to idols, he is uncreated and the source of all continuing life.

children.title: The living God is Father, Son and Holy Spirit
The living God is to be worshipped
Turning away from the living God is sin
The living God contrasts with dead idols
God is the source of life
God gives life to created beings
God sustains the life of all people
God is the source of new life
God, love of
children.comment: The deepest possible expression of God's character. Though God loves all people, he is especially committed to sacrificial, loyal relationships with his people.

children.title: His love is perfectly expressed within the Trinity
The gift of God's Son is a unique act of love
God sets his love on the unlovely
God always acts in love towards believers

primaryrefs.comment: ``Jedidiah'' means ``loved by the LORD''.

seealsos.comment: Benjamin
Ezra
Solomon

children.title: Human love must respond to God's love
Human love must be modelled on God's love
God, majesty of
children.comment: The greatness and splendour of God, revealed in his creation and mighty works of deliverance. On account of his majesty, God is worthy of praise and adoration from all people.

seealsos.comment: The word translated ``glory'' also means ``majesty''

primaryrefs.comment: A figurative expression indicating that God is fully majestic.
``hand'' is a symbol of God's power which accomplishes his purposes.

children.title: The risen Christ shares in God's majesty
God's majesty provides help for his people

secondaryrefs.comment: Habakkuk's description of God's person and work

children.title: Human responses to the majesty of God
God, patience of
children.comment: God shows forbearance in his character, decisions and actions. Above all, he waits patiently for people to turn to him for salvation.

primaryrefs.comment: ``slow to anger'' is the main OT expression for God's patient character.
The Greek can be translated ``God of endurance/patience''.  The phrase suggests that God is patient and imparts patience.

children.title: God's patience lasts a long time
God is patient in delaying punishment
God, perfection of
children.comment: God is complete, faultless and totally sufficient in every aspect of his being and ways. That perfection is made known in Jesus Christ, and is the ultimate goal of the Christian life.

children.title: Humanity should emulate God's moral perfection
Humanity cannot always grasp the perfection of God's ways
Examples of the perfection of God's attributes
God's perfection is seen in Jesus Christ
God, power of
children.comment: God is all-powerful (that is omnipotent), and is able to do whatever he wills. His power is limited only by his character.

children.title: He is the LORD Almighty and God Almighty
children.precomment: ``Almighty'' in these verses is usually Hebrew ``Sabaoth'':

children.title: God's power is seen above all in his acts of redemption
God shows his power in the exodus
God shows his power through the work of Jesus Christ
God shows his power through the proclamation of the good news about Jesus Christ
God's power is shown in Jesus Christ's life
God's power in Jesus Christ's earthly ministry
God's power in Jesus Christ's heavenly ministry

primaryrefs.comment: In contrast to all other priests, Jesus Christ exercises his ministry now in heaven because death could not hold him.

children.title: God's power seen in Jesus Christ's second coming
The Holy Spirit demonstrates God's power
The ark symbolises God's powerful presence
God gives life to the dead
God's power in the lives of believers
God gives his own power to his people
God's power achieves his purposes in his people's lives
God's power completes his work of salvation in believers' lives
God's power gives believers inner strength
God's power is made plain through human weakness
God's power gives help to believers in suffering
God's power is limited only by his character
God's power is to be praised
God, present everywhere
children.comment: God is omnipresent in that he transcends all limitations of space and is present in the fulness of his being in every place but in varying ways.

children.title: God is present throughout heaven and earth
God is near to all human beings
God is present with special groups of people
God is especially close to the poor and needy
God is especially close to those who call on him
God is always present with his people
God is present in believers through the Holy Spirit
God, purpose of
children.comment: God has a plan for his creation which he will certainly accomplish. It is carried out through the control of circumstances and his choice and use of people, and above all in the life, death, resurrection and second coming of Jesus Christ.

children.title: It cannot be thwarted by human beings
It cannot be thwarted by evil powers

seealsos.comment: The implication is that evil is subject to God's control and operates within the determined limits of his sovereign purpose

children.title: It prevails in people's lives and circumstances
It is fulfilled through his choice of individuals

primaryrefs.comment: God's choice of individuals does not invalidate their free will to do or not to do anything, nor remove their answerability to God for their actions.

children.title: Examples of the actions of evil people serving God's purpose
God's purpose is founded on divine wisdom
God's purpose is determined from eternity
God's purpose is for his own glory
God reveals his purpose to his people
Its fulness is beyond human understanding
God's purpose is revealed through Jesus Christ
It is God's purpose to redeem the world through the cross

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ often speaks of his appointed ``hour''.  In John's Gospel in particular his ``hour'' refers to the cross.  Jesus Christ refuses to allow anything except the cross to be the climax of his ministry (Jn 12:27).

children.title: It is God's purpose to exalt and establish Jesus Christ as Lord
Jesus Christ submits to God's purpose
God's ultimate purpose is to save
The salvation of people through Jesus Christ
Specific aspects of God's purpose in salvation

secondaryrefs.comment: that the wisdom of God be revealed

children.title: God wills that people submit to his purposes
God's people should pray for the fulfilment of his purposes
People can reject God's purposes in their lives
Examples of God's purposes being worked out
God, repentance of
children.comment: A change in God's plan or intention, often in response to human repentance, but without implying any fault or moral imperfection on God's part.

children.title: God's repentance may show his pain and sorrow

primaryrefs.comment: God's change of purpose here involves his intention to punish.

children.title: God's repentance may show his compassion

primaryrefs.comment: God's change of purpose here involves his compassion for sinners: ``relent'' in this and other passages may also be translated ``repent''.

children.title: God may repent in response to human repentance
God never repents of his oath or changes his character
God, righteousness of
children.comment: An aspect of God's nature which expresses his unique moral perfection and his readiness to save sinners. It is made known especially through the gospel of Jesus Christ.

children.title: God's righteous acts are saving acts
God's righteousness is seen in his judgments
God's righteousness contrasts with human unrighteousness
God's righteousness is revealed primarily in Jesus Christ
God's righteousness is revealed in the gospel
God gives his righteousness to believers
The Holy Spirit reveals God's righteousness
God's righteousness is to be sought after
God's righteousness is a pattern for human living
God's righteousness is worthy of praise
God, sovereignty of
children.comment: The fact that God is free and able to do all that he wills; that he reigns over all creation and that his will is the final cause of all things. This is often expressed in the language of kingship.

children.title: God is free to do all he wills
God is able to do whatever he wills

primaryrefs.comment: Gabriel speaking to Mary.
From Job's prayer of submission and repentance.

children.title: He is Lord of heaven and earth
His throne is a symbol of his sovereignty

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ teaches his disciples about things to come

children.title: God's sovereignty extends over all things
He is sovereign over human life

primaryrefs.comment: Part of David's prayer on the occasion of gifts being brought to the temple.

children.title: He is sovereign over the minutest details of life
He is sovereign in electing his people
He is sovereign in the life and salvation of his people
He is sovereign over the sufferings of believers
He is sovereign over world history
God is sovereign over all other gods and over demonic forces
God is supreme over all gods

primaryrefs.comment: ``gods'' are part of the created order and subject to God's sovereignty.

children.title: Satan is defeated through God's sovereign purposes at work in Jesus Christ
God, suffering of
children.comment: God suffers on account of the failures and pain of his people, and especially through his Son, Jesus Christ. Scripture often likens God to a parent who suffers pain and grief on account of children.

children.title: He suffers pain because people sin
He is angered because people sin
He suffers with his chosen people

seealsos.comment: God suffers even with those who endure punishment from his own hand

primaryrefs.comment: An indication that God suffers in both disciplining and loving.

children.title: God's plan of salvation causes him suffering
He suffered in giving his Son
He suffers because he endures the rejection his Son suffers

primaryrefs.comment: There is a sense in which the sufferings of Father and Son are indistinguishable.

children.title: God, the eternal
children.comment: God transcends all limitations of time and endures for ever.

children.title: God transcends all concepts of time
God, transcendence of
children.comment: God is far above, beyond and outside the created order.

children.title: God is outside and above all creation

secondaryrefs.comment: Elihu declares the LORD to be beyond reach
Jesus Christ is above all, in the place of highest honour and authority

children.title: God is able also to draw near to his creatures
God is invisible to people and hidden from their sight

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ has made God known
Jesus Christ is the image of God

primaryrefs.comment: These exceptions indicate that God's invisibility is not inherent, but the result of sinful people's inability to look upon a holy God.

children.title: God is made visible in Jesus Christ
Redeemed people will be able to look at God's face
God's ways are beyond human understanding
God, truth of
children.comment: God's unique integrity is displayed in his perfection of character and attributes. It is further emphasised by the consistent truth of his words and works, supremely shown in Jesus Christ.

children.title: God is the one and only true God
God's truth is demonstrated in the revelation of himself in Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: In the light of this statement it may be concluded that truth is actually defined by the person and work of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ and the Spirit bring truth
His words are consistently true and reliable
His words of promise are totally true and trustworthy

seealsos.comment: The guarantee of God's faithfulness is the truthfulness of his promises which depend in turn upon the truth that characterises God himself

children.title: God's people live in the light of his truth
God, truthfulness of
children.comment: To call the LORD ``the true God'' means that he alone has in his being the fulness of deity and is worthy to be worshipped as God. He and his word are a trustworthy foundation for life because he speaks the truth and is utterly reliable and consistent in his character, his revelation of himself, his promises and his pronouncements.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ calls himself ``the true bread'' meaning that he is real, substantial, reliable and life-giving

children.title: God is true to his character and his word
He is true to himself and his promises
The truthfulness of God undergirds the law
The truthfulness of God undergirds the covenant

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew word translated ``faithful'' can also be translated ``true''. The word is particularly associated with God steadfastly upholding his covenant promises.

children.title: The truthfulness of God undergirds the prophetic word
The truthfulness of God undergirds his promises
The truthfulness of God undergirds his judgment
The truthfulness of God undergirds the teaching of Jesus Christ
God, unchangeableness of
children.comment: God's nature, plans and actions do not change even though he is active and his relationships do not remain static. His moral consistency guarantees his commitment to unchanging principles.

children.title: God's purposes and plans do not change
God does not revoke his promises
God's failure to inflict promised judgment is a sign of his unchanging grace
God, uniqueness of
children.comment: No-one and nothing is comparable to the triune God in his nature or comparable to him in his character and activity.

children.title: There is no God except the LORD

primaryrefs.comment: God alone stands outside nature as its Creator. All other beings are created by him.

children.title: God alone is to be worshipped
God, unity of
children.comment: God acts as a unity in all his deeds. The three persons of the Trinity are united in one Godhead. They are interrelated with one another, share the same attributes and co-operate in the same work. God's characteristics are consistent, expressing his integral divine nature.

children.title: The three persons of the Trinity are united in one Godhead

primaryrefs.comment: The interchange between the persons of the Trinity reflects their unity in terms of activity.

children.title: The Son is one with the Father
The Spirit is one with God
The three persons are one in character
All three are called Lord and God
The three persons share in the same work
His love and justice are in unity
His wrath and mercy are in unity

seealsos.comment: It is particularly in the cross of Jesus Christ that the perfect balance between God's wrath and justice and his love and mercy are seen

children.title: God, will of
children.comment: The intent and purpose of God, as revealed in Scripture. God's will for his creation and his people is set out in the Law and the Prophets, which find their fulfilment in Jesus Christ. A central aspect of the will of God is that his people be faithful and obedient.

children.title: God's will is fulfilled in Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ obeyed his Father's will
Jesus Christ's death fulfilled God's will
God desires the world to be saved
God's will for his redeemed people
God desires love for one another
Making radical changes to do God's will
Examples of people who obeyed God's will
God's will and the human will
God's will overrides the desires of the wicked
God's will can harmonise with human wills
God, wisdom of
children.comment: Scripture declares that God alone is wise and discerning, and that human wisdom is often unable or unwilling to understand his ways. God's wisdom is expressed in both creation and redemption.

children.title: God's wisdom is superior to human wisdom
God's wisdom as an agent in creation

primaryrefs.comment: Wisdom here is given personality, and may refer to the pre-incarnate Jesus Christ.

children.title: God's wisdom in knowing the human mind
Jesus Christ the wisdom of God
God gives his wisdom to human beings
God, zeal of
children.comment: The intense and protective commitment of God to his people and to his purposes which seeks a passionate and obedient response. The zeal of God is often linked with the idea of the ``jealousy of God'', in which God refuses to contemplate his people giving their allegiance or affection to another.

children.title: God in his zeal demands exclusive loyalty from his people

primaryrefs.comment: The jealousy of God implies that he seeks for and insists on exclusive loyalty which is due to him and which will benefit those who give it.

children.title: God's zeal for the honour of his name
God's zeal on behalf of his people
God's zeal to establish the Messiah's reign
God's zeal is aroused by his people's idolatry
He restrains his zeal in judgment
God's people appeal for his zeal to be shown
